Tonight Clinton is holding an all-star event in Philly with her, Bill, the Obamas, and entertainment provided by Jon Bon Jovi and Bruce Springsteen. From this I infer:  1) Clinton's internal polling, turnout projections, etc. indicate that she may lose Pennsylvania
2) That her campaign also believes that if Trump wins Pennsylvania, he may win the election
3) That she has given up on the rest of the state, and is relying on the Greater Philly area to take her over the top in Pennsylvania
4) If she's in that much trouble in Pennsylvania, she may be in trouble elsewhere. Pundits have contended for months that Pennsylvania was a slam dunk for her. Now, her last major event before the election is in a state she was supposed to be able to win without even trying. Three or four weeks ago, people were talking about how she might be able to turn Georgia and Texas; today she has to pull out all the stops to lock down Pennsylvania.  My inferences may be wrong; we'll see tomorrow.

With two weeks to go, I'm going back to forecasting a Trump victory. Last summer, I looked at RCP's interactive demographic map, and saw that a slight uptick in white voters over Romney's share four years ago would win Trump the election. This of course, is if everything else from 2012 remained the same or balanced out to not make any net difference. I don't think that Clinton will significantly outperform Obama's victory in 2012. I do think that a lot of middle and working class whites who are registered and have until now not bothered to vote may show up this year and vote for Trump. Trump is the first candidate in the lifetime of most voters who has said what those voters are thinking about immigration, trade, and offshoring. Given that they never previously had a chance to vote for a candidate who they thought represented them, turnout models and poll weighting based on 2012 figures may not be adequate to predict the outcome of this election. I think there will be a much greater turnout of non-college educated white voters this year, and they will swing the election for Trump.   Below are links to two interactive maps that I used to reach the conclusion that Trump will win with only a slight increase (about 5.5%) in the white vote. http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2015/08/26/demographics_and_the_2016_election_scenarios.html http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-swing-the-election/

Trump =
"Word salad"
Word salad is a "confused or unintelligible mixture of seemingly random words and phrases", most often used to describe a symptom of a neurological or mental disorder. The words may or may not be grammatically correct, but are semantically confused to the point that the listener cannot extract any meaning from them. The term is often used in psychiatry as well as in theoretical linguistics to describe a type of grammatical acceptability judgment by native speakers, and in computer programming to describe textual randomization. Word salad may describe a symptom of neurological or psychiatric conditions in which a person attempts to communicate an idea, but words and phrases that may appear to be random and unrelated come out in an incoherent sequence instead. Often, the person is unaware that he or she did not make sense. It appears in people with dementia and schizophrenia, as well as after anoxic brain injury. Clang associations are especially characteristic of mania, as seen in bipolar disorder, as a somewhat more severe variation of flight of ideas. In extreme mania, the patient's speech may become incoherent, with associations markedly loosened, thus presenting as a veritable word salad.

I'm updating my forecast, increasing the chances of a Democrat victory. Previously I laid out 4 scenarios related to wikileaks, which I believe has the best chance of swaying the election away from a Hillary victory. 1, Assange is blowing hot air. The leaks have nothing. Just a rude or ambiguous statement here and there. Currently leaks have already produced more scandals so this is not going to happen. 2, The leaks bring more scandals, but no true bombshells. This is the current state of things. However, these will not be enough, and get minimal media attention, effectively 0% Trump win. 3, A serious bombshell that the press cannot ignore, that puts her on the defensive. 70% Trump victory. 4, The atomic warhead of bombshells. Obama himself can no longer justify letting her walk free. 100% Trump victory. So far the leaks have been on par with scenario 2 with no signs of moving to scenario 3, although Wikileaks may have been planning to save the best for later. However this brings me to an issue I failed to consider earlier. If the material wikileaks has is scenario 3 or 4, then the campaign and the gov are most likely well aware of what wikileaks has and is more likely to take action to stop the leaks from happening. There is some evidence this has started to happen, or that wikileaks expects it to, based on their most recent tweets, consisting of a serious of hashes and a tweet claiming Assange has had his internet cut. EDIT: The latest batch has been released. First, although scenario 3 and 4 are more likely to provoke US intervention, it is still a possibility that they would act in a scenario 2, both to hide non election swaying scandals, and to discourage future leaks that could prove worse. Second, wikileaks has publicized the fact that they are prepared for US intervention, in the form of insurance files and dead mans switches. However, there is no guarantee the US will not be able to discover and disable these in time to stop them. Thus, the chance of scenario 3 and 4 producing a Trump victory will be reduced. Third, I feel I initially gave scenario 2 too low a chance of happening, although the recent events mentioned above would knock it back down a bit. If the leaks stop and don't continue again in a week, and no insurance file keys are released, I will assume nothing more will be released prior to the election. If the leaks do continue again, and the Hillary campaign begins attacking Trump even more heavily, or the US gov takes further action against wikileaks, Ecuador, Russia, or does something else drastic, then I'll assume scenario 3 and 4 are more likely, while not discounting that the flow of leaks could be stopped again. So the bread down is...
Scenario 2, adjusted up to 25% for 0% Trump win.
Scenario 3, adjusted down to 57.5%,  with a 25% of wikileaks being stopped before release, and a 70% if everything gets released.
Scenario 4, adjusted to 17.5% of happening, with a 25% of wikileaks being stopped before release, and a 100% Trump victory if everything gets released.

http://votamatic.org/ How bad is it for Donald Trump? Let’s do the math by Drew • October 11, 2016 • 0 Comments 
Cross-posted at Daily Kos Elections Even before news broke this weekend about Donald Trump’s 2005 Access Hollywood tapes, he had been receiving some extremely bleak polling numbers. As of today, Trump trails Hillary Clinton by 9 points in Virginia, by 8 points in Pennsylvania, by 6 points in Colorado, by 4 points in Florida, and by 3 points in North Carolina. When we run all of these polls though our presidential forecasting model, it predicts that Trump has less than a 10 percent chance of winning the presidency.

Women who Trump molested are coming forward, predictably, after Trump's categorical denial of any misconduct at the debate: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/13/us/politics/donald-trump-women.html?smid=tw-nytpolitics&smtyp=cur&_r=0 I have no trouble at all believing the allegations of these women; I knew a woman years ago who had exactly this kind of thing happen to her, and I know two women who couldn't bring themselves to watch the TV show "Mad Men" because they worked in advertising in Manhattan in the late '60's through the '70's and the show brought back too many distressing memories. OK, it has been a long time since I revised this, but now that both conventions have been held, and neither was technically "contested," though the RNC was a bit testy, and the polls have had time to gather more data, I am revising my estimate for a narrow Dem win at this point in time. Looking at polling accuracy for Aug/Sept and October/November, I found a few interesting things. First, we can discount a third party win as virtually statistically impossible at this point - it has not happened in modern times, and the current 3rd parties see very little support.  What's interesting is that going back to 1960, in every case but one (Carter/Reagan '80), the person ahead in the polls in October won the general election. Even more interesting, the percentage carried by the person *ahead* in October is - on average - bang-on what percentage of the popular vote they carried in the general election. HOWEVER, the percentage of the votes carried by the October *loser* were, on average four percentage points *higher* - possibly due to some sort of voter turnout effect possibly cause by the late polls (I need to look into this further).  Current polls for October average Clinton at 47.8% and Trump at 42.8%. On average, Clinton's score should not change much, and Trump's should *increase* by 4% (again, this is averaging across the last 56 years), which would put them at 47.7% (there is a tiny downward adjustment on average for the October lead) and 46.3%, effectively. Since it's virtually certain that this group of voters will elect the next president, that leaves Clinton with 51% of the voters who count, and Trump with 49% of the voters who count.  There is still a lot of randomness in this campaign that makes that narrow margin subject to huge shifts. Voter turnout could seriously affect the outcome, so that is where both parties need to focus their efforts. Corollary: I dove down a bit deeper into the mechanics of the polls on RCP, and the current October Polls, when correcting for relative size of the polls, taking the best and worst case scenarios for each candidate (given the MOE), and then adjusting as per the historical Polls-to-Popular vote, then taking the average of the best and worst cases, I came up with Clinton finishing with 45.4% of the popular vote to Trump's 43.8%. Assuming these will be the only votes that count (obviously), that doesn't change the overall prediction - 50.9% chance of a Clinton win vs 49.1% for Trump

I've left this prediction sitting for a while, and I really aught to have changed it months ago, and more. After a long, and very unusual election season, we stand with Trump trying to recover from a very well publicized scandal, and GOP leadership, who after never looking like they had much support for him in the first place, now actively throwing him under the bus. First for how the comments themselves will affect him. I believe that most people are not going to change their vote based on them, but you don't need most people to make a difference in an election, and assuming the Brexit effect is in play pushing his actual numbers ahead of the polls, it still probably would've been close without this scandal, which means hardly any voters would need to be swayed to turn that into a loss. As things stand now, I predict its over for him. But this is hardly a normal election cycle. On the other side we have Clinton, dragging scandal after scandal behind her. Avoiding indictment only after the FBI director repeatedly called her incompetent. The fallout of a bitter primary season, with the opposing side feeling like they were cheated. And of course wikileaks. So far this year she's suffered the DNC leaks, the Guccifer 2.0 leaks, dropping plenty for people to get angry about, but no true bombshells and otherwise minimal mainstream media coverage compared to whenever Trump opens his mouth. But with just a month left to go, Assange seems to have placed all his chips down, and declared that these final leaks will end Hillary. To me, if anything might be able to sway this election, it will be this. But lets break down the main possibilities. 1, Assange is blowing hot air. The leaks have nothing. Just a rude or ambiguous statement here and there. 2, The leaks bring more scandals, but no true bombshells. 3, A serious bombshell that the press cannot ignore, that puts her on the defensive. 4, The atomic warhead of bombshells. Obama himself can no longer justify letting her walk free. For the first, leaks have already begun coming out, and have already given us some scandals, and potential scandals if picked up by the press. We're past this stage so it isn't gonna happen. For the second, if the dirt remains par for whats already come out. Collusion to keep Sanders from winning. Shady dealing with donors. Her saying insulting things. More evidence that she ordered her emails deleted and wanted no one to know what was on them. Collusion with journalists to get favorable coverage. Details about her health, etc. In a normal campaign this would be crippling, but I predict that the media will still downplay it in favor of more coverage on Trumps bus comments, or the last five things he said. Leaks of this level will hardly help Trump, even if he rubs them in her face on the third debate. For this case, Hillary still wins. 0% Trump victory. For the third, this would have to be something that would cause serious uproar. Evidence of election fraud, an email with her flat out saying she sold weapons to ISIS and wishes she could sell them more. Proof she helped donors walk away with millions at the expense of the poor. A cartoon villain style confession. These would be leaks that get very close to Assange's bluster. This would be a major blow to her campaign, and at best, put her back to pre bus-gate levels against Trump. Exactly what is found could strongly sway the actual percentages, but I'll say it averages out at a modest advantage for Trump in a fair election. Lets put that at 70% Trump victory. For the fourth, this is effectively what Assange is promising. An email of her ordering someone killed dated just before that person died. Treason against Obama, covering up a rape by Bill, ordering voting machines to be rigged to steal primaries from Sanders. Planned or ordered violent crime, breaking and entering. Something that will end her. Not only would she loose, people will be demanding her in prison. 100% Trump victory Exactly what chances I give each of these is tricky. Assange has been tooting his horn about Hillary all year without much to show as of yet. However, his latest claims go well beyond and should not be completely written off. Since 4 seems to be what he's promising, I'll give it at least 20%. However, all of this being hot air can't be ignored either, so I'll assign another 20% to #2. This would leave 60% left for #3. Assuming a fair election, that's .2*0+.6*.7+.2=.62 so a 62% chance of a Trump victory. To be honest this feels rather high, but these numbers are just a first draft and I'll hopefully remember to revisit them later. But the keyword here is fair. What if theirs cheating? Given the nature of this, we don't really have numbers for how often election fraud occurs, let alone to what extent and let alone at the presidential level. But we have easily hacked voting machines, an electoral college that allows the results of a single state to swing the entire election. And of course, no shortage of accusations. Who seems to be the most likely to resort to cheating to win? Wrong question. Better to ask who is more likely to get away with it. Trump has partly leadership hostile towards him, and a media watching his every move. He wouldn't be able to cheat even if he wanted to. Hillary on the other hand has an extensive powerbase, and an opposing party that might want to push it in her favor too. A completely honest Hillary would need not have a clue if those in her Democrat power base decide to do it for her. Thus, the possibility of cheating would only skew the odds in her favor. However, this would only matter in #3, as in #2 it would make no difference, and #4 its too late. In addition, just because someone tries to cheat, doesn't mean they cheated hard enough, with it being a balancing act between making a difference and not getting caught. Further, cheat in an election that already goes in your favor and you changed nothing. Some rough estimates, I gave #3 70% Trump which are the only cases where it would matter, of that say 60% is close enough to change, lets give it a low %20 chance of attempted cheating. That's 8.4% of cheating changing a #3 towards Hillary, giving new odds of .2*0+.6*.7*(.4+.6*.8)+.2=.57 or 57% Trump victory if we consider the possibility of cheating, unless we find evidence of attempted election fraud against Sanders. With the seriousness of the leaks being the biggest drivers, I'll need to pay close attention to whats being released and adjust based on how likely each possibility seems to be by the end. Its not unlikely Assange would save the worst for later, possibly 2 weeks before the election. As it gets later then that, the odds of something more serious then what we already see goes down. By 1 week, I doubt we'd see anything worse unless we're already at a very strong #3. I'll also consider adjustments to the other percentages, most likely reducing the chance of a Trump victory given #3

Trump called for a Special Prosecutor of Clinton, and predicted she would end up in jail. Trump also lambasted Clinton for her continuing support of Obamacare. These two issues should resonate well many Americans. (+1 Rep /-1 Dem). Trump also demonstrated far superior understanding of the complex issues in the Middle East, in particular, pointing out that there are no "moderate opposition" rebels in Syria (they are all radical jihadists), that Western policy to finance and encourage such rebels is in effect financing and encouraging ISIS, and that such a policy has resulted in split priorities and an overall disaster. It was a bit too sophisticated of an argument for the typical American to take in, much of which was delivered by implication; so I don't expect many Americans to clearly see how it was such a gigantic departure from the unpopulist mainstream narrative. That is, there was a level of nuanced detail that made this an original argument for prime time consumption. In general, Trump tends to exhibit a far greater understanding of policy details than does Clinton. Unfortunately, he does not take the time to educate the typical American, ignorant of why such details matter, on their significance to the debate. Given the recorded statement by Clinton that she finds it useful to maintain a public and private position on policy issues, Trump, instead of seeking to place offensive digs on Clinton, should have adopted the more benign, and potentially more effective, strategy of simply asking: "Is that your public or private position Hillary?" on any policy statement Clinton would have made. [And, of course, while we did not need it, the point that the "informal" system dominates the "formal" political system, made by a leading contemporary practitioner in the trade, is not lost on serious students of organizational dynamics.]

Trump didn't play to his base in the first debate. All of his most solid supporters are furious that he failed to bring up the emails, Benghazi, etc. He seems to be avoiding making any soild attacks on his opponent, which shows he's prepared to exercise self discipline and concentrate on improving his likability.
The 3am tweets bit is an absolute sharknado of an issue - hardly anyone will have even heard of it and even the ones who have don't really care. The fact that Clinton's supporters are celebrating a partial victory in the debate shows how low their expectations are: she's a seasoned politician and debater while this was effectively Trump's first time: why didn't she wipe the floor with him? Trump will do better in each successive debate and the only narrative worth reporting will be of him gradually eclipsing her. Clinton can't do any better than she has already done, and there's still a real risk of her suffering some major health problem that would wholly disqualifiy her in the minds of most voters. Finally, where are his media spots? Is Trump really so averse to having his face on TV that he's willing to sacrifice the few percentage points that TV ads would buy him? It seems more likely that he's waiting for a media blitz closer to the actual vote, rather than diluting his message over a span of months. He's recently been doing better than expected with black voters. If he can create a media campaign that resonates with Black America he can win in a landslide.

The RCP Electoral map has two Toss-ups going back to the Clinton column. The states in question are Virginia and New Hampshire. The interesting thing about New Hampshire is that Trump's loss seems to have parked itself in Johnson's column, and a slight loss by Clinton may have been picked up by Stein. Clinton had pretty solid leads in Virginia all along, so her reclaiming it is no surprise, and in my opinion it was unlikely that Trump had any real shot there anyway. Aside from those two states moving to the Clinton side, the RCP Toss-up column is still quite large at this stage. Here's a link to the map: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/2016_elections_electoral_college_map.html So it's a question of whether enough Toss-ups move back to the Clinton side of the map, where they were throughout of August. Clinton has shown that she can (prospectively) put together enough states to win, but crucially, she can only do that when Trump is at his most idiotic. Polls moved convincingly toward Clinton after Trump insulted Captain Khan's parents, and then just wouldn't let the matter drop. Now, after the debacle of the first debate, Trump went on his Twitter rampage about Miss Universe, and Clinton's numbers are climbing - but tellingly, not by as much as you might think. (Why isn't she leading by fifty points? You might well ask.) If Trump manages to get back on point, Clinton's lead may shrink again.

People are split between fear and apathy. Donald Trump is a TV reality host and a very loud and obnoxious mouth. People believe that this attitude is what is needed now to 'get the job done fast'. What they fail to realize is that there are too many checks and balances in place to keep a president from becoming a dictator -- which is what Trump would do if he had nothing controlling his actions.
On the other hand, Hillery is very lax, but will not rock the boat -- not to mention she would be the first woman president (right after the first African American President) which would be another historical first for the USA. Besides her laid back attitude, people know that Bill Clinton will be in the closet -- ready to pop out and help if the need arises during her term. These things make her popular as a choice.
People are torn between warmongering and at least the pretext of a cool and calm leader (not to mention a first woman leader), But for the first time in history, I believe there is enough unrest that the major independent candidate will get a larger than normal number of votes.

I watched the debate on Monday and this is my takeaway:
- Immediate post-debate consensus was Clinton over Trump, 70% to 30%.
- 81.5mm US viewers on traditional media, largest ever for a presidential debate (100mm, including non-traditional means). Important in that not only were partisan supporters watching, assumes a high percentage of independents and undecideds as well. Hillary’s good, 1st-round showing captures more of these votes. 
- Trump was significantly damaged on two key demographics: African-Americans and women. His response on the Birther question killed him on the first. His overbearing attitude toward Clinton and response to her baiting on his past remarks about women on the second. On visuals, how about this scenario: Fade in. Mr. and Mrs. America are watching the debate. Trump waving his hands and interrupting. Clinton: ”I have a feeling that by the end of the evening, I will be blamed for everything that's ever happened." Trump (snarky): "Why not?" Clinton: ”Why not, yeah, why not? Mr. America: “Haha….. go get ’er, Donald!” Mrs. America (rolling her eyes and thinking): Gosh, Almighty. Trump acts like my Cletus after I burn the meatloaf, put too much starch in his BVDs or put Twinkies into his lunchbox instead of the Ho-Hos.” Fade out.
- On Tuesday’s close, major US stock indices (Dow, Nasdaq, SP500) up higher on perceived Clinton performance. 
- Noticed a change in the Clinton ads for Seattle. Running the ‘ordinary Americans’ ads with veterans and women (the ‘us’ versus ‘him’). Good switchover by Team Clinton. First Trump ad airing now (pretty darn late….. what’s up with the RNC?). Affirming my forecast and will assess after October 9 debate. Social media intelligence (SMI or SOCMINT) refers to the collectives tools and solutions that allow organizations to monitor social channels and conversations, respond to social signals and synthesize social data points into meaningful trends and analysis based on the user's needs. Social media intelligence allows one to collect intelligence gathering from social media sites, using both intrusive or non-intrusive means, from open and closed social networks. The term was coined in a 2012 paper written by Sir David Omand, Jamie Bartlett and Carl Miller for the Centre for the Analysis of Social Media, at the London-based think tank, Demos. The authors argued that social media is now an important part of intelligence and security work, but that technological, analytical and regulatory changes are needed before it can be considered a powerful new form of intelligence, including amendments to the United Kingdom Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000.
Source: Wikipedia
Wired (UK), June 26, 2013, ‘Meet Prism's little brother: Socmint’: http://www.wired.co.uk/article/socmint
Clip from Wired article:
“The intelligence gathering technique -- sometimes known as Social Media Intelligence or Socmint -- has been used in conjunction with an alarming array of sophisticated analytical tools. "Sentiment analysis" that can determine your mood; "horizon scanning" that tries to pre-empt disorder and crime; facial recognition software that can track down individuals; geo-location that is able to pinpoint your whereabouts, and profiling that can map who you are and what circles you move in. All innovative techniques used in the private sector, and all adapted for law enforcement and surveillance.” Open Source Intelligence (blog), October 31, 2012, ‘Social Media Intelligence (SOCMINT) – Same Song, New Melody?’: http://osintblog.org/2012/10/31/social-media-intelligence-socmint-same-song-new-melody/ SiliconValley.com, September 3, ‘Secretive foe attacks Google over government influence’: http://www.siliconvalley.com/2016/09/03/secretive-foe-attacks-google-over-government-influence/

Random observations from first presidential debate.
• Trump started out very strong by focusing on jobs and economic policies. Once the moderator asked a question which had implications which might impugn his personality, however, and further lured from that point forward by Clinton with personal jabs, Trump reverted to his same old name-calling and buffoonery. He is, after all, or so he at least claims, a counter-puncher. His counter-punching did not serve him well. He had the initiative and he lost it.
• Trump hammered on specific job and economic examples (e.g. an unfair tax differential between Mexico and the U.S., which actually impedes fair trade, to the detriment of the United States), Clinton responded with generalities and platitudes, and invoked the old "independent experts" mantra. I was so waiting for the famous Michael Gove comeback ("I think people in this country have had enough of experts"), but it was not to be. Trump missed his chance to obtain an early knockout blow on economic policy. Clinton was on the ropes, she was going to stand behind NAFTA, and he let her off the hook. NAFTA supporters consider free trade a system to be maximized. If you're a proper leader, you'd think of NAFTA as a mechanism by which the system of free trade could be optimized for the benefit of your country. In the latter case, NAFTA has failed miserably.
• Trump, when pressed by Clinton on his business management practices, more-or-less 'fessed up to screwing over the suppliers, vendors, and contractors that he uses. Trump implied it was all OK, because he only "took advantage of the laws of the nation." The "rule of law" is not justice, and screwing over contractors is inflicting harm. Laborers and sole proprietor contractors don't have the wherewithal to challenge the likes of Trump in court for a ten thousand dollar contract dispute. So Trump screws over a hundred contractors for ten thousand dollars each, and it adds up. When injustice is done, and the system allows those who have perpetrated the injustice to get away with it (impunity), resentment against not only the wrongdoer, but the society at large ensues. We all pay the price for such improper behavior. First, we finance the legal system that enables such practices; and secondly, such practices sap the spirit of goodwill, efficiency, and fair dealing that are necessary for a coherent society, thus feeding the false narrative of zero-sum transactional economics. It's a crappy business practice (it's plain theft buttressed with intimidation under color of law); but hey, that's Trump.
• In response to a question on race relations and "bridging the racial divide" (which, of course, presupposes that such a divide in fact exists), neither candidate addressed the question, and both quickly answered with criminal justice and enforcement plans ("law and order"). My goodness. Doesn't that just speak tons about how those candidates truly feel about race relations! The fact is, race relations are generally good, the minority communities are suffering the effect of the economic depression more so than the population as a whole, and the issue is therefore an economic issue. Crime is a separate issue.
• Both candidates plan to spit on the Second Amendment by disallowing citizens that are on the so-called "terrorist watchlist" from obtaining weapons. This, of course, is hogwash, for not only does it fly in the face of the language of the Second Amendment itself ("the right ... shall not be infringed"), but the very purpose of the Second Amendment was to protect the citizenry from a government that runs amok. You can't very well then give to the government the right to create a secret watchlist (or any list for that matter) that prevents that right from being exercised! But this whole debate was a tour de force in muddled thinking.
• Trump is all good with the idea that the priority mission of NATO should be re-purposed so as to combat terrorism. In fact, Trump would like to claim this new direction for NATO to be a result of his idea and prompting. This is not good news for those that believe the entire terrorist phenomenon is an intentionally constructed narrative to distract and deceive. Once Trump connects his self-esteem with an issue, rationality goes out the window.
• Trump continued to seek to differentiate himself as not being a "professional politician," and repeatedly associated Clinton with a class of "political hacks" that have made poor economic and foreign policy decisions. Clinton invoked her panic button-like catch all "fact checker" squad. When confronted with the notion that her "experience," claimed to be related to poor policy decisions, was not something to be touted, Clinton sheepishly chose not to argue the case. It was a perfect opportunity for her to dive in to her accomplishments, but her silence surrendered the point.
• I imagine each candidate gets to select some number of audience attendees. Trump keeps rolling out Don King, the boxing promoter. Professional boxing in the United States, since at least the 1920s, has been routinely fixed. I think the selection of King by Trump speaks volumes as to what Trump values.
• Perhaps it was the stress of Clinton trying to land a last minute blow when the clock was ticking down, but the accusation that Trump believes "women don't deserve equal pay unless they do as good a job as a man" somehow left me with, "Well, yeah. So?" I guess the accusation might be that Trump thinks that it is conceivable that women in general are not capable of performing as well as men, but this is not what he said; and the real principle must be that the pay is based on the job, whatever that is, irrespective of the sex (or whatever other characteristic) of the worker. So I think Trump was trying to articulate the principle, and the over-reaching by Clinton came across as reaching for straws.
• Trump cited a Clinton reference as springing from "the mainstream media." Just as Trump has done with free trade, for a major party presidential candidate to even utter those words in a nationally televised debate, in the totally controlled propaganda environment that is the United States, opens up the minds of millions of citizens, and gives them permission to even contemplate the notion of a national media dominated by "political hacks." 
• The prognostication by Trump during the primaries that he would "crush" Clinton in a one-on-one debate proved false. In fact, in terms of debate finesse, Clinton clearly had the better of Trump by luring him away from policy issues into personal areas where he felt challenged and responded immaturely.
• In his closing remarks, Trump made a vague reference to some potential new accusation of Clinton scandal that, apparently, is so bad that even he, Donald Trump, felt it was in better taste to avoid mentioning. Then, of course, why did he mention it? It was a panic move, but maybe it appeals to soap opera fans. I don't know. Is this campaign a soap opera or a cartoon? 
• All in all it was a disappointing exhibition, with no knockout blow from either candidate, The good news is that neither candidate broke out of the cartoon character stereotype, so there's still a chance for a third party miracle!

This seems like a good year to be especially wary of the Bradley Effect, caused by respondents telling pollsters what the respondents think is the Okey-Dokey answer but doing something else on the Tuesday.  This year it could actually work both directions, depending on where the respondents live--Clinton supporters living in Texas are in roughly same boat, mutatis mutandis, as Trump supporters living in Vermont.   However, if it kicks in big nationwide, the polls are understating Trump's support in the popular nationwide vote. It is nonetheless important at all times to remember that popular vote is largely irrelevant in US presidential elections.  If the Bradley-effect Trumpsters live in New York or California, it won't matter.  If they live in Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Florida, it might very well matter.  Probably a good autumn season is in store for those who make and distribute bourbon.

The media talks of "horse race" coverage of the election, but it has been many decades since journalists were regulars at the track. This narrowing of horizons has not served them well during this campaign. As the horses reach the home stretch, a newcomer to the races views the horse in the lead is most likely to win. A veteran will look at the horses to see which are moving easily and which are struggling. He will observe the jockeys to see which are frantically urging their mounts and which are calmly waiting for the the most opportune time to unleash the final kick. Experience has taught the veteran that an unhurried rider atop a steady-going horse is the likely victor over a harried jockey on a hard-pressed horse, even when the latter leads by a few lengths. In the presidential race it's not difficult to identify the candidate sputtering through the final furlong and the one running easily despite trailing at the eighth pole. But in elections, as in racing, the only pole that matters is the one at the finish line.

For the purposes of the electoral college, however, this doesn't matter, assuming he can manage to hold onto Arizona, Georgia, and North Carolina. This means that Clinton could well do WORSE in the electoral college than she will in the popular vote (contrary to the popular misconception).  This is, at this point, a very close election that Trump has excellent chances in.  Furthermore, a little more speculatively, let's look at the lessons of the Brexit vote. We all punted on that, myself included, because of a swathe of traditional non-voters who showed up to vote who did not get picked up in the pre-election polling, specially in phone polls. These non-voters showed up because the Leave campaign fed them an appealing populist message with clear-cut, simple, understandable, emotionally appealing themes. The Trump campaign hasn't been as slick, but it shares a lot of the same characteristics. The LA Times/Daybreak tracking poll includes a chunk of these voters - people who didn't vote in 2012 but say they plan to in 2016 - and Trump is up +6 in that poll...

http://www.cbsnews.com/news/republican-it-guru-dies-in-plane-crash/ [Fair Notice: The Clinton email scandal is not as clear-cut as it might seem. Research has revealed a very mixed-up history of email and other communications by government employees. For instance, there is the so-called Hatch Act which restricts the use of governmental systems for political activity. This act, in effect, forces governmental employees with political activities to maintain two separate communication systems. There is also, apparently, a not-so-pretty history of email and other communication systems being set-up to accommodate adherence to this act, and for other purposes, that gets very grisly and extends well back into the Bush-era. Whether the vulnerabilities introduced by the Hatch Act were planned, or only arose as recognized opportunities of exploitation, I do not know. What's obvious, however, is that the entire issue of personal, political. governmental business (including secret) electronic communications by high-level governmental employees (overlapping into the private sector) has a real history that's not generally understood. In such an environment the claim that Clinton mishandled classified information would be an easy claim to make. At that level, with such a mixed-up system environment, the same claim could be made against a host of other government employees; including, as I've said, those extending into the Bush-era. The history would not (fully) exculpate Clinton, but it would cast light somewhat on the greater context in which her activities took place. It's a little surprising that no Democratic loyalists have gone into this dark past of political communication, at least in some attempt to take the heat off Clinton. It makes me think that, like Watergate, there's some evil infestation of both parties lurking in the background.]

Any good enforcement agency would have seized every server and device immediately, long ago. But Clinton didn't just run-the-risk that Powell described. Oh no, she upped the ante! She took ALL of her correspondence into a non-governmental-system computer, not just some (as had Powell). So yes, Powell should be subject to some discipline as well. But his forthright email to Clinton was more of a "notice" of the parameters of accountability as it was anything else. She knew the parameters, decided to run-the-risk, and got caught. Sounds like intention to me. One thing about Powell though. I don't think he'll sell out his credibility, unlike Comey and Lynch.

As noted previously ( http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/315003 ), there is growing evidence that the black community is far less united behind Clinton than some media commentators initially believed. Many community leaders are stepping back from full-throated endorsements of Clinton ("make up your own mind"), while others are even going so far as to support the ABC movement ("make up your own mind, so long as it's Anybody But Clinton"). The only voice I have seen that is solidly and consistently behind Clinton is Black Lives Matter, and this group I would classify as an extreme radical (on the verge of violence) far-left element.* All other voices, including both mainstream and strongly activist (albeit non-violent) voices in this community seem to be genuinely undecided (or perhaps better stated, not so strongly committed). In this respect the black community mirrors the nation as a whole. Trump just needs to do *something* for these disaffected black (historically-)Democratic voters for them to break ranks en masse with the local Democratic party machines and vote for him come November. He has not found the "magic symbol" for this yet. (-1 Dem / +1 Other)
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/05/us/politics/young-blacks-voice-skepticism-on-hillary-clinton-worrying-democrats.html * Black Lives Matter is an interesting group. It sprung up more-or-less simultaneously in a dozen or so urban areas. This, to my mind, is a sign of some form of national coordination. Having watched various protests by this group in various locations, I find that each group is reciting chants out of the same book. The chants are identical. This, to me, is another sign of centralized coordination; in particular because these chants are not traditional protest songs, but somewhat unique to this group alone. These are new, provocative chants promoting aggressive action. This is far more than an airing of grievances. Even if the issues they feel that they face are outrageous and intolerable, language promoting aggressive response is not the way to go.

While reading the following article in regard to the Asean-led Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) question, I was struck with two things:
1) How closely the world is following this U.S. presidential election, and weaving it into their own local narratives to suit their own purposes; and 2) How wrong this author may be about Donald Trump.
http://www.nationmultimedia.com/opinion/Asia-must-take-charge-of-its-future-30292958.html To many Americans, myself included, the phenomenon that is Donald Trump is inexplicable. But I disagree with the author when he implies that all of Trump's actions are in some sense false and coldly calculated to achieve maximum effect. Rather, I'm beginning to think that what may be endearing to some portion of the American electorate is that, while some veil of secrecy is expected, with only a little scratching the true nature of Trump reveals itself. That is, there is something *genuine* about Trump; even if what is revealed is some definite craziness. When Trump shoots-from-the-hip, as he so often does, that's the real Trump; that is not an act. The logic then is that while Trump may genuinely be a jerk, at least he is genuine. While the extended reasoning may be in error, I do maintain that Trump is *not* acting when he says and acts the way that he does. That's the real Trump.

"Unusual" accounting: Inside a Trump business audit
http://www.cbsnews.com/news/inside-a-donald-trump-audit-missing-books-and-unusual-accounting/ There is a pox upon both houses. "they are certain that Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders won the California Democratic primary, but election fraud robbed him of a victory."
http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2016/aug/03/judge-rules-in-election-case-bernie-sanders/ The opinion of this judge in this case reminds me of how auditors handle "material weakness" in a client. A material weakness is where there is a good chance that something significant may not be known about a company, and yet it does not prevent an auditor from certifying the books. I've never understood this approach. It's like saying "The 90% of the transactions we can evaluate are fine, but there are 10% that we have no idea about, and while it is true that those 10% may offset all of the gains or losses in the 90%, we're still fine with saying everything is OK." How can this be? They simply do not know. It's as if admitting that one does not know, by itself, somehow adds extra-special-certainty back upon something that one already knew, and this magically transforms what is not known into something that is no longer relevant. The logic that recognizing a gap in knowledge diminishes the potential defect caused by that gap escapes me. In this instance, fraudulent "mail-in votes that arrived later and provisional ballots" could have stolen the election. No one knows, since these were not audited. Again, exactly the way material weaknesses are treated. We've got a problem. no one knows it's impact (although it could have swung the election), but hey, let's move on, we've got other things to do! The more rational option would seem to be to invalidate the entire general claim (i.e., the books are OK, the election was good) and throw it back upon the parties to sort it out, with the risk of such sorting falling upon the parties making the claim, not those parties relying upon the claim that has been made.

I am changing my general forecast from about mid-70s Clinton to 90% Clinton. I took my state-by-state forecast, simulated 10 battleground states plus the 240 "comfortable" EVs Clinton would have from the NYT forecast (minus VA, in the GJO set, but plus NH, NM). Out of 200 simulations with state results independent, all 200 went to Clinton. Ever since being tipped off to the SENSEI consortium by @k13rkeg44rd, I admit to being enamored with their use of adjective analysis as part of their Brexit study. Although they did not (I don't think) undertake any extension of their analysis, I think it remains an interesting idea how far one might be able to go with such an extension. The basic notion is this: SENSEI created a word cloud that seemingly ranked associated adjectives within each Brexit camp. Visual inspection of the cloud indicated that the leading adjective for the Remain camp was "Stronger" whereas the leading adjective for the Leave camp was "Right." My wonder is whether these results can be turned into some sort of predictive measure by blind polling of people upon the sentimental preference between adjectives. That is, how would a random sample of people respond when forced to make a preferential choice based on the words alone? An underlying presumption of such an indirect study would be that one could gain some indication of future conscious choice by gaining insight into current, associated, subliminal disposition (or some psycho-babble like that). Despite having been warned-off such an indirect approach as being a bit too squishy, I'm constantly reminded of it whenever I see the Clinton "Stronger Together" theme. I'm not sure if "stronger" would rise to the top of the Clinton adjective word cloud, but if it did, it would be an interesting curiosity because the same word was top for one of the Brexit camps. I don't know if there is a leading Trump adjective, or if the magnitude of the leading adjectives of each candidate are comparable (or even if such relative scaling between adjective "power" is included in a comparative display -- is #1 on each camp displayed with equal intensity or is there a relative aspect both within and between adjective displays?). In any case, the SENSEI consortium seems not to be running such an adjective analysis for the U.S. presidential election, so I'm asking if anyone is aware of any group that is.

A view from Australia (a land of odd politics itself). This is not a typical election - more uncertainty and risk with polar opinions, and (unlike Australia) without compulsory voting more hinges on who turns up on the day rather than just who likes whom. Moreover protest votes now have consequences (a Brexit style lesson which may not have reached America) and based on the Democrat convention  the Clinton campaign appears to have  moved into the sort of professionalism with grassroots vote gathering that should win swing states. Trump has surprised as a billionaire anti-establishment candidate, and could win if  fear wild cards appear and they fall his way but he now looks less attractive as the reality of approaches of a president "outside normal parameters" even for P.J. O'Rourke confronts voters. Importantly- while most  Australian's and our media may think Trump is a figure of fun - we don't vote and don't count. The lesson from the month long count for the final seat in our national election (won by 30 votes) is - all that couts is votes on the day in swing seats.

Trump is too easily goaded. (+1 Dem) Democrats take bits and pieces of DNC speech by Mr. Khan, father of slain Muslim U.S. serviceman, and attack Trump for his plan to "ban immigration of all Muslims." Trump, rather than recognizing the sacrifice of Mr. Khan and reiterating his (admittedly quite extreme) position that "immigration of Muslims is to be SUSPENDED until the issues of documentation and vetting can be properly sorted out," engages aggressively on the topic. Instead of just falling back and clarifying his previous position, Trump, in a knee-jerk fashion, engages the father in a media battle as to "who has made the greater sacrifice for America," and follows up with a formal statement rebutting various claims of Mr. Khan (including the fact that Trump has indeed read the Constitution). It's rather shocking that Trump allowed himself to be drawn into such a no-win losing battle. Now, since there is *nothing* to be gained by winning a battle against the father of a deceased serviceman, either Trump wants to appeal to bigots, or he really handled this interchange very poorly. The proper response would have been:
1) Acknowledge the sacrifice of the Khan family
2) Move immediately to a clarification of his position (de-spinning the DNC spin)
and 3) leave it up to some campaign spokesperson later to put on the record that Trump loves to read the Constitution. If this were a fencing match, we'd say that Trump lacks appreciation of the subtleties of the skill of "parrying." His response to this attack was to attack, but he fails to appreciate the fact that his attack was initiated not by himself, but by his opponent. His attack is a reaction, and not an action. Not that there are never any situations in which an immediate counter-attack is not best, but this was definitely not one of those situations. Poll Finds Voters in Both Parties Unhappy With Their Candidates
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/15/us/politics/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-poll.html "In a development not seen in any modern presidential contest, more than half of all voters hold unfavorable views of the two major party candidates and large majorities say neither is honest and trustworthy." The NYT seems to be the first to explore the ramifications of this ASTOUNDING historical novelty, even if just by tip-toeing into it. In the same article they introduce the notion of "issues" as possibly being a discriminator between candidates. (Hooray!) Unfortunately, with the exception of "the Wall," the identified issues are rather vague. Every one of those blue dots in the middle of the graphic are issues to which the Republicans can tie a concrete proposal to (e.g. the Wall) and "steal" Democrats that are inclined in that direction already. (I say this despite the fact that the Wall fared poorly. Trump doesn't need all Democrats, just a bunch.) Theoretically, the same could be said in a vice versa fashion for the three red dots at the bottom, but the concrete proposals seem less obvious. It also seems that Clinton continuing to tie herself to Obama's performance is a losing strategy. Maybe this brief foray into comparative issue analysis is all we'll get, and the rhetoric will continue to be on personality bashing (We get it, they're both dangerous kleptomaniacal lunatics). But maybe, if we're lucky, some enterprising pollster will lay out the concrete, tangible policy proposals, and we'll get a good idea of whose policies are preferred.

Top bucket up 2% from Other. I thought more US States had changed the way they allocate Electors. I was wrong. Johnson would possibly have to win at least one Electoral vote if the 12th Amendment really requires that one of the three considered by the House have an Electoral vote. —not at all clear if selecting between two candidates is allowed. (from Wikipedia on Electoral College): "Contingent presidential election by House[edit] 
Pursuant to the Twelfth Amendment, the House of Representatives is required to go into session immediately to vote for president if no candidate for president receives a majority of the electoral votes (since 1964, 270 of the 538 electoral votes). In this event, the House of Representatives is limited to choosing from among the three candidates who received the most electoral votes. Each state delegation votes en bloc – each delegation having a single vote; the District of Columbia does not receive a vote. A candidate must receive an absolute majority of state delegation votes (i.e., at present, a minimum of 26 votes) in order for that candidate to become the President-elect. Additionally, delegations from at least two-thirds of all the states must be present for voting to take place. The House continues balloting until it elects a president. The House of Representatives has chosen the president only twice: in 1801 under Article II, Section 1, Clause 3 and in 1825 under the Twelfth Amendment." http://www.270towin.com/content/split-electoral-votes-maine-and-nebraska/

I am referring to labor and working-class Democrats joining economic conservative Republications.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JK4WNA1aBUQ Watch this video and tell me that you can't see how these policies might not appeal to base Democrats. And, he's boxed Clinton out on these issues at the same time. Don't underestimate this coalition. It would strip the base support away from both the ultra socially conservative Republicans and the ultra liberal Democratic ideologues. If this coalition catches on, and Trump continues with a rhetoric against which Clinton has no rebuttal, it will be a far closer race than many are predicting. It's a coalition that has the potential to not only win the election, but to break the parties. Trump is a bozo. A dangerous bozo. He is no less corrupt than Clinton. Republican Senator Susan Collins Says She Might Support Hillary Clinton
http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/republican-senator-susan-collins-says-she-might-support-hillary-clinton Um, I guess if you read it in just the right way, and interpolate some number of carefully selected words, you might be able to get from "I’m not going to say never" to "I might support." More importantly, however, Collins, and the rest of the GOP establishment just don't get it. The fact that Trump is not politically correct, and is likely a racist, a bully, and an overall jerk, doesn't matter. That he's stupid, a snake-oil salesman, a blowhard, a front for organized crime, or whatever, also doesn't seem to matter. Everybody already knows these things. There must be something else that is attractive about Trump to the voters. Could it possibly be a sheer repudiation of the "mainstream" policies of both parties? It's possible the mainstream policies of the parties just do not align with the wishes and desires of mainstream America. The political correctness aside, is it the mainstream political parties that are "off the mark," not Trump? It's a precarious situation. Trump, a flawed individual, may be more in tune with the pulse of the society (e.g., jobs, fair trade, limited military adventurism, not allowing political nicety to interfere with substance, etc) than any so-called mainstream candidate. It's not a good combination. For the past twenty years or so it seems that the American populace has continually, in one fashion or another, voted for "change," (e.g., Obama's pledge to repeal the Patriot Act, midterm repudiation of the democrats), anything to get the buggers out, only to be disappointed when the new group picks up exactly where the old group left off. I see Trump's popularity as a continuation of this desire for real substantive change (the undying hope of naive citizens?), now made manifest in a flawed candidate. I do not believe this continuous underlying impulse for change will be held off by appeal to political correctness, or even candidate qualifications or competence. It's an affective action, and it's a dangerous situation. From a cybernetic (system control) perspective, a sitting GOP senator waffling as to supporting the party candidate, and the no-doubt-about-it crazy candidate himself, are strong indications that the system can't handle this perturbation (the underlying drive for democratic [not socialist] change) and is headed toward massive disequilibrium. Edit: Strike the idea that Trump supports a non-interventionist foreign policy. Huge wall of text incoming. You have been warned. (Used the same reasoning already, so if you feel you have seen this comment before, it's because GJP was kind enough to give us the same question twice.) Let's get the obvious out of the way here first: A third party is not going to win. Yes, each election there are whispers that now, finally, we will see the end of the two-party system that everyone moans about. But let's face it: Nobody votes third party. So, a third party has no hope of winning. Now, as to Donkeys vs Elephants.  We can be quite certain that for the republicans, Trump will be the nominee. Barring any sudden surprises (such as him dying), there is nobody that can realistically oppose his nomination. 
On the dems side, it is quite certain that Hillary Clinton is going to win the nomination (yes, Bernie Sanders is fighting tooth and nail, but let's face it, his nomination is highly unlikely).  This makes things simple: It will be a Clinton vs Trump battle. Let's look at the republicans first: Trump keeps befuddling pundits by rising further and further in the polls. Yes, everyone is having a stab at him. Seemingly everyone hates him. And yet, in spite of constant ridicule, cynicism and derision from all sides (from the political system, the media, celebrities, you name it), his popularity only seems to keep growing. For a while, each time he said something even more outrageous, the standard response was: "You can't say that and stay in the race!". And each time, the pundits were proved wrong. Yes, Trump gives every impression that he will make a career-ending mistake any second now. But people who have been holding their breath for it have long since suffocated. So, let us for now assume that Trump will not just vanish from the scene as has been endlessly predicted and repredicted. Let us further assume the best case for him: He manages to unify his party and to get the support of those people who are still undecided. If we follow this trend, his popularity will probably grow a bit more before plateauing.
In his favor he has the support of a great number of people, as well as his novelty factor and the fact that everyone perceives him to be "outside the political establishment". Against him he has his often ludicrous remarks and statements, such as building the wall and having a foreign state pay for it. His opponent is sure to bring this up and run with it as far as possible. Onwards to the democrats:
Hillary Clinton seems very popular and until very recently, her presidency seemed all but certain. Lately, it feels as if the wind in her sails has quieted down a bit.
Against her, she has of course that she is perceived to be the typical, run-of-the-mill backstabbing and bootlicking politician, "tainted by a thousand shabby deals". There are a lot of accusations against Hillary Clinton from quite a few different sides, including corruption from foreign states and of course, everyone's favorite darling, the Benghazi affair.
In favor of her is that she is a woman and that she would be the first female American president, a fact she is milking like there is no tomorrow. Quite a lot of people will vote her for that single fact alone. She is also very experienced and knows how to play the political game. She can probably mobilize the dems against a fractured GOP. In addition, she has amazing support, especially from the media. Indeed, there are even reports that Twitter has even gone so far to make anti-Hillary hashtags vanish from its platform. Which brings us to the essential question: Who will win? For a question like that, we consult the polls and use this as an anchor. So far, Clinton has always had a comfortable lead over Trump. But it is important to note: This lead has typically been around 10%. That would mean as a baseline, Dem:Rep ~ 60:40. But popular vote means little in the United States, where the electoral system is strange at best and outright crazy at worst. Since this is difficult to foresee without a lot of effort, I am adjusting this baserate downwards, closer to 50:50. Can we attempt a prediction on who will win that goes beyond the current polls? This is where we risk being murky. Taking the points raised above into account, I give a slight lead to Clinton, simply because the game is a lot easier for her than it is for trump. She has support from the establishment and a very devoted following, he only has support from his voters and only enemies everywhere else. She is experienced and has lucrative connections, he probably knows less about the political game.  How much will all this influence the election? Right now, it's impossible to say. You may come up with a thousand more reasons why one candidate or the other is advantaged. This is just what I saw as the most important and the most deciding. But even then, I will not stray far from my initial prediction. PS: Lately, Trump has been gaining ground over Clinton. I will keep monitoring carefully.

MARTIAL LAW: http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/martial_law.aspx
"Martial law on the national level may be declared by Congress or the president. Under Article I, Section 8, Clause 15, of the Constitution, Congress has the power "[t]o provide for calling forth the Militia to execute the Laws of the Union, suppress insurrections and repel Invasions." Article II, Section 2, Clause 1, of the Constitution declares that "[t]he President shall be Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States, and of the Militia of the several States, when called into the actual Service of the United States." Neither constitutional provision includes a direct reference to martial law. However, the Supreme Court has interpreted both to allow the declaration of martial law by the president or Congress. On the state level, a governor may declare martial law within her or his own state. The power to do so usually is granted in the state constitution."

So , based on feedback from previous predictions, and with Indiana's win for Trump and Sanders, I have restructured this - and the numbers come back even better for Trump, which surprises me a bit. I'm also assuming an additional condition in this question - that this means Trump wins an *uncontested* nomination.
The base rate problem: of the 34 historical elections between R and D, R's have won 18 to D's 16 - this is the most favorable base rate to D - since it includes the FDR years, etc., but it is unrealistic, as the current balance (southern states being almost exclusively red) happened with Kennedy and beyond. Still, that gives a 53% chance of a Republican victory. I next looked at the electoral votes (as was recommended), but since this is heavily influenced by the great migration after the 1960's of the "Dixiecrats" to the Repubs, I think it's only wise to go back to Kennedy. Of the total electoral votes cast since 1960, Rs have won approximately 54%, so that is another marker. Finally, I measured each state's individual electoral contributions to R and D votes respectively since 1960, and gave each state a P(R). An exhaustive random model of all states (r with their probabilities for R or D resulted in a surprising 64.7% advantage to Republicans. Averaging the three (just for argument's sake), I came out with a 57% likelihood of  a republican victory. (Trump doesn't enter into this, except to assume he is the *uncontested* winner) I did consider the head-to-head polls, but when I examined the Gallup poll results for president since 1960, I discovered that the poll results for the April/May timeframe for each election were no more accurate than a coin toss, and in the past 12 years, they've been wrong 66% of the time. Therefore, I did not modify the score based upon the head-to-head polls, as it's just too early in the cycle to do that.

Time for some updating. Sam Wang points us to some data that suggests HRC has a tad better than a 4-to-1 advantage over Mr. Trump in November. Why? The short answer has to do with the fact that direct match-up polls have started to have predictive value (because of our current place in the election cycle). The long answer is worth reading, but Wang surely does a better job of explaining it[1] than I would, so I suggest taking him for a spin, if you're into these things.  I think that Wong's input is useful, but only one of many sources from which to draw. Foxiness militates against using only a single model or theory to try to predict very messy events like a presidential election. (Or is relying of foxiness itself also "one big thing"? Never mind.) Other input, like the fact that it's unusual for a single party to hold the White House from more than 2 terms at a time, suggests a rather different outcome. We'll see.... --- [1] http://election.princeton.edu/2016/05/01/what-do-head-to-head-general-election-polls-tell-us-about-november/

I've increased the odds in favor of a republican victory. Looking at past elections, a party that has held the presidency for 2 terms usually fails to keep it for a third. Starting with Ike, there have been a total of six presidential elections in which the same party held the white house for the previous two terms, and of those six, only one, Bush 1, managed to win a third term for his party. So 5/6=83% in favor of a republican. Since Bush v Gore was so close, I nudged it to 4.75/6=79% as my baseline. I'll admit starting with Ike is a bit arbitrary, but FDR's long run by no means happened in ordinary circumstances, and the further back we go, the more different the political landscape was. I consider it too early in the election season to consider Trump v Clinton head to head polls. As for the candidates themselves, Trump is a rather polarizing figure, who seems able to both rally people to his side, and turn people against him. Without something else to go on, I'll treat both as equal and canceling each other out. Since this is conditional, I don't need to consider a brokered convention.

Trump has a distinctive personality. It is easier to remember what he stands for than for Hillary. Trump channels the frustration that the American public feels, into a rally cry for change. Lower median wages, automatization of labor, the sharing economy, outsourcing to China, corporate excesses have made people feel powerless. Hillary represents the establishment, and voting on her does not help alleviate the feeling of frustration. Voting for Trump might. Hillary is not a likable person, although her last name might have positive associations in some voters' minds. Trump is also entertaining, interesting and provides hope for change. I believe that his support for protectionism and building walls against Mexico resonates with voters - it provides a feeling of being cared for and supported. Voters who on an intellectual level realize the dangers of such policies are very few and are unlikely to impact the election to any major extent. There has been a recent trend of populist candidates winning elections, from Austria to Sweden to the Philippines (most likely). Google Trend search query numbers indicate significantly higher interest in Trump than Hillary. Nate Silver was originally negative on Trump's chances of winning the election, potentially causing other forecasters on this website to become skeptical about his chances. However Nate recently conceded that Trump against all expectations have beaten his polling averages in the last six states. Just like Duterte seems likely to win the Philippines elections, I believe that Trump will beat the low expectations with progressively higher polls and ultimately win the election in November

I think Trump's winning of the Republican nomination is likely to trigger the entrance of one or more independent candidates into the race.  Depending on who they are (e.g., Bloomberg), they will siphon off votes from the Republican ticket or both tickets.  A stronger (more "moderate", better-connected) candidate like Bloomberg would draw off more Clinton votes.  A weaker independent candidate (like any of the now side-lined Republicans) would affect Clinton less.  Since I can't know who will enter the race, I'm forecasting an average effect of a race involving strong- and weak- 3rd party candidates.  The percentages I predict roughly correspond to shares of the popular vote I would anticipate going to each party under those hypothetical scenarios.

I'm reducing the odds of a Dem victory from 80 to 70%, and increasing the odds of a third-party win from 0 to 10% since Romney launched his attack on Trump and some members of the GOP establishment started talking about a third-party run against Trump. That led me to look up the rules of both allocating electoral college votes and what happens in case the electoral college can't come up with a clear majority in favor of a single candidate. Here's what I learned:  "What is the difference between the winner-takes-all rule and proportional voting, and which states follow which rule? The District of Columbia and 48 states have a winner-takes-all rule for the Electoral College. In these States, whichever candidate receives a majority of the popular vote, or a plurality of the popular vote (less than 50 percent but more than any other candidate), takes all of the state’s Electoral votes. Only two states, Nebraska and Maine, do not follow the winner-takes-all rule. In those states, there could be a split of Electoral votes among candidates through the state’s system for proportional allocation of votes. For example, Maine has four Electoral votes and two Congressional districts. It awards one Electoral vote per Congressional district and two by the state-wide, “at-large” vote. It is possible for Candidate A to win the first district and receive one Electoral vote, Candidate B to win the second district and receive one Electoral vote, and Candidate C, who finished a close second in both the first and second districts, to win the two at-large Electoral votes. Although this is a possible scenario, it has not actually happened. What happens if no presidential candidate gets 270 Electoral votes? If no candidate receives a majority of Electoral votes, the House of Representatives elects the President from the 3 Presidential candidates who received the most Electoral votes. Each state delegation has one vote. The Senate would elect the Vice President from the 2 Vice Presidential candidates with the most Electoral votes. Each Senator would cast one vote for Vice President. If the House of Representatives fails to elect a President by Inauguration Day, the Vice-President Elect serves as acting President until the deadlock is resolved in the House." Source: http://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/faq.html

Trump is in a unique position of being an underdog from the perspective of traditional politics: he has alienated large parts of the general electorate and the GOP establishment is against him. However, he is rewriting the rules of campaigning. If he also ends up rewriting the rules of GOP and national politics, traditional analytical tools of electorates (Nate Silver's "follow the endorsements," etc.) would probably no longer apply. The odds of such a scenario, which would lead to a Trump presidency, have increased tremendously in recent weeks. However, assigning high odds to such a scenario assumes the disruptions evidenced in the current campaign thus far will continue in the face of all challenges. Maybe it's because I'm not a Trump fan, but I cannot stomach the idea of a Trump presidency, and have to believe that Americans will eventually do the right thing (i.e., not vote for Trump as president). For this question, I think Trump's ongoing momentum, lack of a formidable opponent, and clear desperation from the GOP establishment leads me to believe he will win the GOP nomination. But beyond that, Trump's antagonistic posture against several electorate groups and national unfavorable rating still lead me to predict that the Democratic party would win nomination. I am increasing odds of an Other winner if Trump wins GOP nomination for two foreseeable circumstances: (a) Trump wins GOP nomination, gets pissed off by someone high up in the party, pooh-poohs the nomination and runs as an independent, and (b) a new person emerges (perhaps Bloomberg). I am lowering odds of a Trump presidency by the odds of this potential outcome.

We're clearly in a major realignment, thus the 2% for an "other" (which I'd normally put at essentially 0%).  Trump suffers from the low floor/high ceiling, and I think this puts his odds well below 50% of winning.  However, there is a runaway effect that can happen with a guy like Trump, in that he and his authoritarian streak not only reflect the public, but it alters the public itself.  These runaway effects can be very, very hard to predict when they will spark, but once they do spark normal expectations go out the window.  Given that all logic pointed me to thinking he'd never get 10% as far as he already has, I increase my sense that we might be in a runaway moment. One also has to consider the incredible weakness of Hillary Clinton as a candidate, beset by scandal, less associated with the high times of the '90s and her husband's tenure (many millennials can now vote and have no memory of this golden era), doing worse in a lot of ways than she did in 2008 under more favorable conditions, the standard 2 term turnaround of party control, etc.  Overall, I think a President Cruz or a President Rubio is more likely than a President Clinton II, but the condition of this question presumes that Trump wins the GOP nomination.  I still give that possibility <50% probability, and still think Trump as the nominee helps Clinton more than anyone else.

With a Trump nomination, I originally gave him a 27% to win, based mostly on gambling markets. We may not like Trump, but he is very intelligent and calculating. He is skilled at theater, having run a reality TV show and been a master of the media for decades. Trump launched his campaign with no policy specifics, attacking Mexicans and Muslims. He has combined to voting groups for his surprisingly good performance: those that dislike Washington, and the lesser-educated blue collar group to which his racism and bigotry appeal. This was no accident. Trump calculated (and everyone missed) that a coalition of these two groups -- those angry at the system, and the racist lot angry at their lot in life, would be enough to get at least a plurality, if not a majority of GOP primary voters. Trump doesn't want to build a wall any more than he hates Mexicans, Blacks, or distrusts Muslims. His statements leading us to believe that are simply part of his theatrical production. He has masterfully sold himself, at low cost thanks to the US media, to those two groups. We are going to see a gradual rebranding of Trump over the next four months as his position strengthens. We've already started to see that. Trump was willing to call out the unjustified Iraqi war as a blunder, and has admitted that Planned Parenthood provides some good health services.  We have no idea what Trump would do as a president, and we have no idea what positions he will take. He is an unknown quantity. In an election, where voters are trying to pick between the lessor of two evils, the unknown quantity might be preferable to them than the evil they know and can measure. I'm raising Trump's odds of winning from 27 to 40% if he wins the nomination. If Clinton continues to show well, it will go up even higher.

Going up on R.  Notes: 
*I'm assuming that HRC is the D nominee. 
*Also, this is the same analysis from the the other presidential question, because I assumed there that Trump would be the nominee. Part of the reason that I am making that assumption is the analysis below, in which I find Trump to be a surprisingly competitive republican candidate. 
*I suspect that before too much longer a significant number of officials in the republican party will look at these numbers and come to the same conclusion. This confirms my earlier suspicion that a "brokered" convention is unlikely, though I still want to sit down and look at the number of R delegates already pledged and still up for grabs. Interesting piece in the NYT from December: "Mr. Trump appears to hold his greatest strength among people like these — registered Democrats who identify as Republican leaners — with 43 percent of their support . . ." "His strength in the South is blunted only by Ted Cruz in Texas and Mike Huckabee in Arkansas . . . Mr. Trump fares well in Florida despite the political histories of Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio in the state." "Mr. Trump’s strength fades as one heads west. Nearly all of his weakest states — 16 of his worst 19 — lie west of the Mississippi." http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/31/upshot/donald-trumps-strongest-supporters-a-certain-kind-of-democrat.html So lets apply that to the electoral results. Here are the 5 closest states by vote % won by Obama in 2012, along with the number of electoral college delegates they each have: FL (29 EC votes)- D: 50.1% R: 49.1% 
OH (18 EC votes)- D: 50.1% R: 48.2% 
VA (13 EC votes)- D: 50.8% R: 47.8% 
CO (9 EC votes)- D: 51.2% R: 46.5% 
PA (20 EC votes)- D: 52.0% R: 46.8% 
http://elections.nbcnews.com/ns/politics/2012/all/president/#.VtX7i_krLRZ Observations: 
*Romney received 206 EC votes in 2012 and Obama got 332, with 270 needed to win. 
*Looking at the figures above, all but PA were decided within a 5% margin, and PA was 5.4%. 
*All of the remaining states that went for Obama did so by significantly larger margins-at least 7%. 
*Only one Romney state was even close to a 5% margin, and that was NC (51% to 48%). 1. First, the easy question. Is HRC likely to win NC? No. Being in the southeast and having a large number of D-registered voters that lean republican, I'm guessing that if anything the republicans increase their margin of victory in NC for 2016. 2. Now the hard question: Can DT pick up enough EC votes to win? 
-2(a). Given his trouble in western states, I don't think he wins CO. This means that he must win FL, because PA, OH, and VA don't get him to 270. 
-2(b). Given his success in the south, I think he wins FL. My probability: 80% (He's kicking Rubio's ass there: http://townhall.com/tipsheet/mattvespa/2016/02/29/qpoll-trump-has-yuge-lead-over-everyone-in-florida-n2126007) 
-2(c). If he wins FL, can he win OH and PA? (VA, with 13 EC votes, doesn't get him to 270 w/o CO.) Yes, I think there's at least a 50% chance of that. Both OH and PA are pretty blue-colar states, and PA has the advantage of being close to Trump's home turf. So 80% times 50% means 40% chance of winning.
