To make this initial prediction, I am using the "mathematical models can help" method of CHAMPSKNOW. To start, I look at the polls for the general election which pit Trump versus the potential Democratic nominees, Clinton and Sanders. While these polls can sometimes be unreliable, I think there are a good starting point (potentially even a good "comparison class"), and given their consistency across one another, I think they work for the time being.  Looking at RealClearPolitics' most recent general elections polls (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/latest_polls/pres_general/), in every "General Election" contest where Trump is pitted against a Dem candidate (both Clinton and Sanders), the Democrats lead, in some by double digits. Because of this mathematical start, I will submit the initial prediction of 75% chance of Dems winning if Trump is the nominee.

I find it difficult to give much weight to conventional political reasoning about Trump's appeal, viability, favorability ratings and the like. Strategically, Trump has upside potential from merely appearing reasonable during the general election campaign. He does not need to adopt the same aggressive tone with Clinton that he adopted in order to break out from the GOP primary pack; he may actively consider it a risk to do so (e.g., with women), which I think is accurate. The contrast between his "straight talk" and Clinton's will be, in my view, a strong theme for Trump. I think Clinton should have the edge on merit, but I think the consensus misjudges Trump's ability to reposition himself (as he has done with apparent electoral impunity on an almost weekly basis).

National polls have consistently showed Trump trailing Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders in a hypothetical one-on-one general election. The most recent poll from CNN (http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2016/images/02/29/rel4b.-.2016.general.pdf) shows Clinton winning 52% to 44% and a 55% 43% victory for Sanders versus Trump in a theoretical general election.  Also took into account Trump's poor net favorability rating that will likely hinder him in a national election with a more moderate electorate. That said, there are examples of candidates winning elections after such early polling, so his chances shouldn't be completely dismissed. I have OTH at 1% to take into account the combined probabilities Bloomberg(or another independent candidate) entering the race (which is closely tied to the probability of Sanders winning the DEM nomination) and their chance of winning a three-way runoff. I would preferred to have this at .5%, but wanted to note the potential.

As of February 28, 2016,  if Donald Trump were the GOP candidate, it appears there is not greater than a ~6% probability Trump would win the U.S. Presidency in 2016; not greater than ~4% a third party candidate would win; and not less than a ~90% probability the Democratic candidate (regardless of who that candidate is). This assessment is based upon the following assumptions/assessments as of February 27, 2016: 	1. To become POTUS, a candidate must:

		a. Win at least 270 Electoral College votes, based upon the popular vote in each state and D.C.; or
		b. Stop the opposition party from winning in the Electoral College, and then prevail in an election conducted in the U.S. House of Representatives under Article II, Sec. 1 of the U.S. Constitution.

	2. To win the Presidency through the Electoral College, Trump would be required to win in VA, FL, OH and CO -- a loss in any of those is highly likely to result in Trump being unable to garner the required 270 Electoral College votes. This assessment is based upon historical voting trends from the 1992 through 2012 U.S. Presidential elections. When the states which have voted Democratic at least 2/3ds of the time in those elections are allocated to the Democratic candidate, and the balance sorted by electoral votes (high to low) those states emerge as those which are determinative of the outcome in a contest between 2 candidates. Iowa could be added to this list, but using this methodology, Iowa is mathematically irrelevant if Trump were to fail in any one of the above 4 states. 

	3. The probability Trump would win in ALL of those states is assessed at ~3%. He currently is ~11 pts behind in VA; nearly even in FL and OH; and ~11 pts ahead in CO. His VA weakness is based upon very high "dislike" for him among the VA voters -- which dislike is based upon the very behavior which has made him the GOP frontrunner in other states -- his confrontational style. Therefore, he is not likely to be able to cure the negative impact of his confrontational style with respect to the probable outcome in VA while simultaneously maintaining that style for its value elsewhere. While he could benefit from new negatives surfacing regarding a Democratic candidate (e.g., possible negative impact of Clinton Wall Street Speech transcripts; continued State Dept. email issues for Clinton), for a net positive change regarding this chance node Trump also would have to avoid additional negatives for him (e.g., problems related to the content of his tax returns; problems related to Trump University and other lawsuits). Assuming Trump's future "negative" events are less problematic for his candidacy Assessing Trump's likelihood of victory in VA to be 5%; in FL to be 75% (which gives him the benefit of the doubt in a currently even race); in OH to be 75% (on the same assumptions as FL); and in CO to be 90% (on assumptions more favorable to Trump in CO than employed in favor of the Democratic candidate in VA), the probability Trump would win ALL of those states is assessed at ~3% (.5 x .75 x .75 x .9 = 0.26718; "say" 3%).    

	4. Unless a Trump loss in more than 3 of those states is the result of a third party victory in each of them, the related Electoral College votes would be won by the Democratic nominee, which would likely be sufficient for that candidate to win at least 270 Electoral College votes and the presidency. As noted below, the probability of a third party candidate winning at least 3 of those contests is assessed at <1%.

	5. The probability a third party candidate would win in any three of VA, FL, OH & CO approaches zero. To do so, a third party candidate would need to exist, and as of this date there is no such candidacy. While former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg has indicated possible interest, contingent upon whether Trump is the GOP nominee, filing deadlines for a Bloomberg candidacy will arrive before the results of the GOP nominating process have been completed. Further, existing polling data indicate that Bloomberg would have serious difficulty in mounting a credible third party campaign at this late date. Therefore, the probability that a Trump loss in 3 of 4 of VA, FL, OH & CO would be the result of a third party win in each of those lost states <1%.

	6. If a third party candidate won least 3 of those contests, the probability that as the Republican candidate Trump would be elected President by the House is >80%. The rules for such an election provide that each state delegate must vote for one of the persons who has garnered Electoral College votes, and each delegation has 1 vote. The Republican Party controls a majority of state delegations in the U.S. House. Therefore, if Trump were able to move the election from the U.S. Electorate to the U.S. House of Representatives, he would very likely be elected as President.

	7. However, a necessary limiting condition regarding a "Victory Through the House" scenario is the probability an election in the House would occur, in the first instance. Since that probability is assessed at <1%, the probability that Trump would win the presidency through the House is negligible, at best.

	8. Because there are ~8 months until the general election, the probability that "unknown unknowns" will have a material impact on the course of the various campaigns and the resulting election is arbitrarily assessed at ~10% (entropy). That uncertainty is allocated equally, 3.33% to the probability Trump would win and 3.33% to the probability the Democratic nominee would win; and 3.33% to the probability of a third party victory.

Therefore, as of February 28, 2016, I assess the probability the U.S. presidential election would be won by Trump as the GOP candidate at not greater than ~6% (~3% probability of a Trump win in each of VA, FL, OH & CO + 3.33% entropy adjustment); the probability an independent candidate would win at not greater than 4% (<1% probability of victory + ~3.33% entropy adjustment); and the probability the Democratic candidate would win at  not less than ~90% (~97% probability of a "not Trump" outcome -  1% probability of a third party victory - 6.66% [say 7%] entropy adjustment*).  [*The Trump and third party entropy adjustments are upward, while the Democratic adjustment is downward, because entropy in this context appears more likely to favor the underdog(s); my description of the probabilities are "not greater than" as to Trump and a third party candidate and "not less than" as to the Democratic candidate; and the question presented establishes mutually exclusive outcomes.]

I broke the question down into four subcategories: Trump v. Clinton, Trump v. Sanders, Trump v. Clinton v. Independent and Trump v. Sanders v. Independent. (Independent here mostly meaning Michael Bloomberg but not exclusively).
Clinton has to be seen as the heavy favourite to win the Democrat nod; Sanders is well back of the thresholds set out by 538 for him to win the nomination. I'd say it's 75-80% she wins. If she does, the likelihood of an independent bid is quite low, as it has been reported that Bloomberg is unlikely to enter the race unless it is a Sanders v. Trump bid. In a head-to-head match, Clinton's favourability ratings are far higher than Trump's and have been for some time and both are well-known figures within the general electorate so it seems valid to give Clinton a substantial lead; I'm guessing but I'd say this by a 2:1 margin.
In the event of a Sanders victory, the situation becomes much less clear. Bloomberg's history of prevarication needs to be factored in, and another prominent independent candidate seems unlikely. Even in this case I'd say it's only 40% that Bloomberg even runs.
Sanders is nowhere near as well known as Clinton, so favourability ratings may lie and the head-to-head polling at this point is rarely predictive. I don't know how to resolve this clash of unlikely candidates. I'm inclined to give Sanders a slight edge because Trump's favourability numbers are so bad and I'm also inclined to factor in a small chance of a win by Bloomberg or some other independent candidate in this scenario.

I currently rate the likelihood of Trump winning the Republican nomination at 47%, so the urgency of this question is only a coin flip away. An unweighted average of polls taken since the beginning of 2016 has HRC over Trump by 7.7%, with a standard deviation of 6.4%[1]. Hence, HRC wins 88% of the time, and Trump wins 12% of the time. And an unweighted average of polls taken since the beginning of 2016 has Bernie over Trump by 8.1% with a standard deviation of 5.9%[2]. Thus, Bernie wins 91% of the time, and Trump wins 9% of the time. Currently, I think HRC has 91% chance of winning the Democratic primary, with Bernie following at 9%. (It's just a coincidence that the 91%/9% split shows up twice.) So that means we can carve up the probability space into four unevenly sized quadrants:  HRC wins the Democratic nomination (0.91) and beats Trump (0.88) = 0.80
HRC wins the Democratic nomination (0.91) but loses to Trump (0.12) = 0.11
Bernie wins the Democratic nomination (0.09) and beats Trump (0.91) = 0.08
Bernie wins the Democratic nomination (0.09) but loses to Trump (0.09) = 0.01 The result is that Republicans have a 9% chance of winning the election, if Trump is the nominee.  End of story, right? Probably not. My average of polls was, as I said, unweighted, and not all polls are equal. I didn't use a weighted average because (a) the off-the-shelf weighted averages from, for example, RealClearPolitics and Pollster disagree quite sharply in some cases and (b) I don't have a reliable weighting algorithm of my own (nor am I likely to have one any time soon). Furthermore, there are very few polls to average, so sample sizes are low. And, polls at this stage of the game have limited predictive value. Finally, the presidential contest is only indirectly (though strongly) related to individual preferences for one candidate or another. It's possible to lose the popular vote but when the electoral college, as has happened within living memory.  So how to take all of the problems with the information we have into account without just throwing up our hands? I propose that following: The principle of insufficient reason[3] suggests that we should assign equal likelihood to states when the probability of their occurrence is unknown. Extending the principle a bit, we can say that we should assign equal likelihood to states when the probability of their occurrence is perfectly unknown, but we should assign a weighted average of equal likelihoods and likelihoods based on what evidence that we have when the probability of their occurrence is imperfectly unknown. For instance, an outcome might be unknown imperfectly to a degree of 75%. We could estimate this in this way: (0.75)(Outcome A*0.5 + Outcome B*0.5) + (0.25)(Outcome A*known probability of Outcome A + Outcome B*known probability of Outcome B). And so on. Call this discounting a forecast by the principle of insufficient reason, where we can discount by any real number between 0 and 1, inclusive. On the basis of all of this, I estimate we should discount the polling data above by the principle of insufficient reason at a rate of 70%. On this basis the probability that a Republican will win, given that Trump is the nominee is currently (0.7)*(0.5) + (0.3)*(0.09)=0.38. Conversely, the probability that a Democrat will win, given that Trump is the nominee is currently (0.7)*(0.5) + (0.3)*(0.91)=0.62. Furthermore, I postulate that the degree of ignorance will diminish by - let's just say - 10% points per month as we get closer to the election. So at the end of the month, I can (and will!) update the likelihood with new polling data (and anything else I can find), discounting this information by the principle of insufficient reason at a rate of 60%.  (Note: this forecast revisits and updates some material I've discussed in forecasting a related question or two.) --- [1]Data about individual polls was taken from http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/us/general_election_trump_vs_clinton-5491.html. However, I did not use RCP's weighting algorithm.  [2]Data about individual polls was taken from http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/2016_presidential_race.html. However, I did not use RCP's weighting algorithm.  [3] http://mathworld.wolfram.com/PrincipleofInsufficientReason.html

As with any other prediction here, this is mostly based on my guesses and intuition. 538 has written extensively on the complete lack of predictive powers of general election polls at this point and, frankly, I agree with Nate Silver that if Trump is the Republican nominee, we're in uncharted waters for what could happen. My assumptions in making this forecast: 1. Trump wins at an uncontested convention but with lip service support from the RNC (most likely though not guaranteed).
2. Clinton wins the Democratic nomination (which I think is highly likely).
3. There is no major third party candidate (your guess is as good as mine).
4. The economy makes slow improvement over the next few months as the economy adjusts to significantly lower oil prices (possible - things have been slowly resetting over the last few weeks).
5. The ISIS situation remains more or less the same. Thoughts:
1. Trump's and Clinton's Unfavorability Ratings Will Likely Change, but He Will Remain Behind Her: Clinton has a good lead. Trump's Ratings ( http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/donald-trump-favorable-rating) and Clinton's (http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/hillary-clinton-favorable-rating).
2. Trump's Something of a Misfit in the Republican Arena: The Trump coalition is odd to say the least. In South Carolina, Trump's base was a little all over the place but he lost values voters and did much less well with those who were "dissatisfied but not angry" with government (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/2016-election/primaries/south-carolina-exit-poll/). The entrance polls in Nevada show somewhat different results, but I don't give them as much credence because IA demonstrated how wrong caucus entrance polls can be. I'm getting the impression that the Republican coalition is going to have an exceptionally hard time holding together support for Trump.
3. A true variable: Can Clinton energize young people and minority voters like Obama did? If so, she's a lock. If not, Trump's chances grow exponentially. We need to see how polls look after Sanders is officially out.
4. True variable: Does Bloomberg jump in? If so, Clinton likely wins a plurality. Questions I have:
1. What is the relative value of the favorability scores (i.e. At what point does an individual's dislike of Trump force them to either vote for Clinton or not vote at all and vice versa?)
2. What states are actually in play in this scenario (i.e. We know have a lot of certainty about how some individual states will vote in this election. For example, CA and MA will go blue and MS and WY will go red. However, are swing states particularly inclined to go one direction or another based on the candidates or are typically reliable states in play? Two states I'd watch: Indiana and North Carolina. Both flipped in 2008 to Obama and then back to Romney. If they're competitive in 2016, that's a very good sign for Clinton. If NH is competitive, that's a good sign for Trump.)?

Donald Trump is a very polarizing figure within the Republican Party and is disliked among Democratic voters. Regardless of who ends up running against him on the Democratic side I would expect a Trump candidacy to mobilize Democratic voters in full force in an attempt to deny a Trump Presidency based on his very poor performance in favorability polls among Democratic voters. Since a Trump candidacy is likely to face such a strong opposition from Democratic voters he would require a very strong coalition of Republican voters in order to win the general election. With the current of the state of the Republican party being so fragmented this seems unlikely to occur, especially since Trump performs very poorly in favorability polls among moderates and independents. I have a lot of difficulty seeing him be able to succeed in the general election without winning over moderate Republican voters, even if he does mobilize the rest of the party. The only viable path to the White House I can envision for Trump is to paint the eventual Democratic nominee in such a negative light that he is able to unify the Republican party against the Democrats. This is certainly a possibility since he would be running against either a self described Democratic Socialist or an establishment Democrat who served a big role in the Obama and Bill Clinton Administrations. However I am still unsure of his ability to win over moderates and independents, and the more that the Republican establishment attacks him during the primary (which Rubio's performance during the Feb 25th Debate would point towards) the harder a job I think that becomes. As well I think there is an incredible amount for the Democrats to attack Trump on in an attempt to win over moderates. While I think Trump has a possible path to the White House, I think it requires a lot of things to fall into place for him and it seems unlikely that they will.

Trump adjustment: -3%

I think many forecasters are underestimating Trump's strength. I think Trump has a good chance of gaining support of moderate voters and blue-collar Democrats. I think anyone who is not a yellow-dog Democrat may vote for Trump. Trump has previously supported Planned Parenthood and had a pro-choice stance. He may decide to modify these positions, but on the other hand he may not feel the need. Trump can toss the Republican social conservative baggage overboard, since he can subtract values voters from his total and still win. Evangelicals may stay home, but they won't vote for Hillary. Many voters view Trump as a clown, but just as many view Hillary as Richard Nixon in drag. As always, the RCP polls are misleading; the totals never add up to 100%. So the question is, despite the apparent pro-Hillary margins, which way will all these undecideds break in November? My guess is that they will break for Trump, who despite his high name recognition is far less of a known quantity politically that Hillary is. Obviously a lot can happen between now and then, but Trump has proven he can ride out things that, according to received wisdom, would sink any conventional politician.

(Note: I'm also predicting HRC is the D nominee.) I think Trump turns off too many people to win, though I do think he has a decent chance of picking up more right-leaning democratic and independent voters in swing states than we might otherwise think.

The base probabilities for this question are the ones I gave for "Who will win the 2016 US presidential election?": DEM 75, REP 25,  more pro-DEM than consensus. But those probabilities must be corrected in order to take into account the fact that they were built for a generic Republican candidate (which according to my  "Who will win the Republican Party nomination for the US presidential election?" question has 85% probabilities of being Donald Trump). So this generic Republican candidate  is a weighted "mix" of all candidates made up of 85% Trump. A very weird (and probably very wrong!) assumption but let's run with it. :-)  So,  we will have to find out if Donald Trump  will be in a better or worse position to beat the Democratic candidate (a weighted mix made of 95% Hillary and 5% Sanders :-) :-) ) than the generic Republican candidate I built my base forecast upon. My take is that yes, Donald Trump may work better than the generic Republican against Hillary for two reasons: - He will take the Red States as the conservative voters have no better choice than Donald Trump (but then those states are already lost to the Democrats) -  On the other hand, results (in Nevada, for example) and polls (in Massachusetts) indicate that Donald Trump works better in swing and blue states than his rivals on the Republican field. In fact, I suspect the Red States are Donald Trump's weak(est) suit (it is only a suspicion yet to be confirmed by fact :-) ). I will not go so far as giving Donald Trump the victory because he has great difficulties with non-White, non-Male, non-Blue Collar voters. Here is my forecast: DEM: 64%  because it is 85% of 75% (the base probabiilty for DEM  is 75% and the same generic Republican is 85% Trump so the probability must be corrected) accordingly :-) ) 
REP:  36%  This forecast is really weird (but I had lots of fun thinking about it over lunch time)  and I really welcome suggestions and criticism.

Which party will win the US Presidential election if (1) Donald Trump wins the Republican nomination and (2) if Donald Trump does not win the nomination (Just to cover all bases, if Trump isn't nominated as a Republican but goes on to win the Presidential election as an independent, the question would be declared void, as it would if any independent won). Given the inherent Democratic advantage in the Electoral College, where they basically start with between 230-240 electoral votes, in solid blue states, and the Republicans start with about 190, I give Trump zero chance to win any of the "swing states" needed to win an election. Obama beat Romney 332-206, in 2012, and I doubt if Trump can do better. There is a marvelous tool on Nate Silvers website that projects the electoral vote (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-swing-the-election/) based on projected demographic variables.   I tinkered with one variable from the 2012, Hispanic vote, Obama received 71%, and got 332 electoral votes. I changed that to 90% (keeping voter turnout the same) and the Democratic nominee would get 352, AZ and NC change to blue. The only way I could get Trump to a victory using the tool was to increase the Non-College Whites, from 62% R to 78% R with and increase in turnout and that included 29% of Hispanics voting for Trump. Needless to say I find this scenario implausible. My gut tells me they have zero chance but I am going with 10%.

I would like to see Chevy produce better automobiles; it doesn’t mean that I’m going to buy a Chevy. I don’t think that Trump can win, frankly, because I don’t think there are enough morons to elect him. A certain percentage of the American public is just morons; that’s the way it is. When you divide the public in two then divide the voters in one of those halves among five candidates or more, a candidate can win by dominating the moron vote because it only takes about one-seventh of the total population to take the “lead” under those circumstances. But when you’re talking about needing 51 percent of the whole population, rather than needing 30 percent of half of the population, you run out of morons. I hope we will. I hope Trump will lose, because I hope he runs out of morons to vote for him.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Keys_to_the_White_House Based on a Keys analysis: "Answers to the questions posed in the Keys require the kinds of judgments that historians typically make about the past. But the judgments are constrained by explicit definitions of each Key. For example, a contested incumbent party nomination is defined as one in which the losing candidates combined secured at least one-third of the delegate votes. . . .  to qualify as charismatic and turn key 12 or 13 – the most judgmental of all keys—an incumbent or challenging-party candidate must measure up to Ronald Reagan, John F Kennedy, Benjamin Franklin and Theodore Roosevelt. 
. . . 
"The Keys retrospectively account for the popular vote winners of every presidential election from 1860 through 1980 and prospectively forecast the popular-vote winners of all eight presidential elections from 1984 through 2012. "The Keys are statements that favor the re-election of the incumbent party. When five or fewer statements are false, the incumbent party is predicted to win; when six or more are false, the challenging party is predicted to win. "1.  Party Mandate: After the midterm elections, the incumbent party holds more seats in the U.S. House of Representatives than after the previous midterm elections.
2.  Contest: There is no serious contest for the incumbent party nomination.
3.  Incumbency: The incumbent party candidate is the sitting president.
4.  Third party: There is no significant third party or independent campaign.
5.  Short term economy: The economy is not in recession during the election campaign.
6.  Long term economy: Real per capita economic growth during the term equals or exceeds mean growth during the previous two terms.
7.  Policy change: The incumbent administration effects major changes in national policy.
8.  Social unrest: There is no sustained social unrest during the term.
9.  Scandal: The incumbent administration is untainted by major scandal.
10.  Foreign/military failure: The incumbent administration suffers no major failure in foreign or military affairs.
11.  Foreign/military success: The incumbent administration achieves a major success in foreign or military affairs.
12.  Incumbent charisma: The incumbent party candidate is charismatic or a national hero.
13.  Challenger charisma: The challenging party candidate is not charismatic or a national hero.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  People who have studied this method of analysis and are familiar with how to judge the criteria say that there's only 4 "NO" keys  .  I, however, am uncertain that there aren't more, so I'm forecasting less than 100%.
~~~~~~~

He says 1,3,7 & 12 are against Democrats, 2,4 & 10 are undetermined at this time, and the rest work against Republicans
